verses.text: Then I watched as the Lamb opened one of the seven seals, and I heard one of the four living beings say with a voice like thunder, 'Come!'
verses.comment: The Lamb, identified earlier as Christ, initiates the unveiling of God's divine plan. The four living beings echo the imagery from Ezekiel, showing continuity between the Old and New Covenants. Christ’s authority to open the seals highlights His divine kingship and unique status as the mediator between God and humanity (see Rev. 5:6-9).

verses.text: I looked, and there was a white horse. Its rider held a bow, and he was given a crown, and he rode out as a conqueror, determined to conquer.
verses.comment: The white horse may symbolize victory or conquest; some see it prefiguring the coming of Christ, others as representing conquest in general. The fact the rider receives authority ('was given a crown') points to God's sovereignty even amidst unfolding chaos (cf. Zech. 6:1-8). The color white is associated with righteousness, indicating a possible link to divine judgment.

verses.text: When he opened the second seal, I heard the second living being say, 'Come!'
verses.comment: The seals are being opened one at a time, showing an order to God's plan. Each living being summoning the riders demonstrates creation's cooperation with God’s judgment and providence.

verses.text: Another horse, fiery red, went out. Its rider was permitted to take peace from the earth, causing people to slaughter one another, and he was given a large sword.
verses.comment: The red horse symbolizes war and bloodshed. The permission given to the rider reflects God’s ultimate control over history, even amid human conflict. For similar prophecies, see Matthew 24 and Ezekiel 21.

verses.text: When he opened the third seal, I heard the third living being say, 'Come!' I looked, and there was a black horse; its rider held a pair of scales in his hand.
verses.comment: Black is often connected to famine and scarcity in Scripture (Lev. 26:26). The scales indicate rationing, pointing to a time of severe economic hardship. The measured judgment here underlines divine justice playing out in concrete historical realities.

verses.text: And I heard something like a voice among the four living beings, saying, 'A quart of wheat for a denarius, and three quarts of barley for a denarius; and do not harm the oil and the wine.'
verses.comment: The high prices signify extreme scarcity, a day's wage for meager rations. The protection of oil and wine may symbolize God’s restraint, limiting the judgment to prevent total destruction. Food scarcity is a recurring sign of judgment in Scripture.

verses.text: When he opened the fourth seal, I heard the voice of the fourth living being say, 'Come!'
verses.comment: With each new seal, the severity increases. Revelation’s pattern recalls the plagues of Egypt: a sign of God’s judgment and call to repentance. The ‘fourth’ reflects biblical themes of universality and completeness.

verses.text: I looked, and there was a pale horse. Its rider’s name was Death, and Hades followed with him. They were given authority over a fourth of the earth, to kill with sword and famine and plague and by the wild beasts of the earth.
verses.comment: The pale horse—the color of decay or sickness—brings death and destruction, accompanied by Hades, the realm of the dead, suggesting both physical and spiritual consequences. This mirrors Old Testament warnings (Jer. 15, Lev. 26). God’s sovereignty in allowing only a limited judgment (a fourth of the earth) exemplifies justice mingled with mercy.

verses.text: When he opened the fifth seal, I saw beneath the altar the souls of those who had been slain because of the word of God and because of the testimony they had maintained.
verses.comment: The vision shifts from earthly judgment to heavenly realities. The martyrs under the altar allude to the Old Testament sacrificial system, where blood was poured out at the altar’s base (cf. Lev. 4:7). Their presence signifies their offering and intercessory role before God, a reminder of the spiritual value of suffering for faith (see Rev. 20:4; Ps. 79:11).

verses.text: They cried out with a loud voice, 'How long, O Master, holy and true, before you judge and avenge our blood on those who dwell on the earth?'
verses.comment: The plea echoes the psalms and prophets (Ps. 94; Hab. 1:2), longing for divine justice. The martyrs show a deep trust in God’s righteousness. Their intercession highlights the union of the saints with God and the continued ministry of prayer for the Church on earth.

verses.text: Then each of them was given a white robe, and they were told to rest a little longer, until the number of their fellow servants and their brothers who were to be slain, as they themselves had been, was complete.
verses.comment: White robes signify victory, purity, and vindication. This verse indicates God’s providential timing: the suffering of the righteous has meaning and is not purposeless. The mention of others yet to be martyred suggests an ongoing witness and unity among believers across time.

verses.text: I looked when he opened the sixth seal, and there was a great earthquake. The sun turned black like sackcloth made of hair, and the whole moon became like blood.
verses.comment: The cosmic signs mirror Old Testament apocalyptic imagery (Isa. 13, Joel 2) and are echoed by Jesus in Matthew 24. Apocalyptic imagery often reflects both literal upheaval and spiritual realities: God intervening in history and unveiling hidden truths.

verses.text: The stars of the sky fell to the earth, as a fig tree drops its unripe figs when shaken by a strong wind.
verses.comment: This imagery of falling stars symbolizes cosmic upheaval and judgment, a recurring theme in prophetic literature (Isa. 34:4). The fig tree image adds a sense of suddenness and inevitability of divine judgment.

verses.text: The sky was split apart like a scroll being rolled up, and every mountain and island was moved from its place.
verses.comment: Major disturbances symbolize the total transformation accompanying God’s intervention. Nothing in creation is secure before His judgment. The scroll imagery alludes to the written Word being fulfilled and unsealed for all to see (Isa. 34:4).

verses.text: Then the kings of the earth, the great and the rich, the commanders, and the powerful, and every slave and free person, hid themselves in the caves and among the rocks of the mountains.
verses.comment: Judgment is universal; all stand equally before God regardless of status. The desire to hide from divine wrath underscores the futility of worldly power in the face of divine authority (Isa. 2:19).

verses.text: They called to the mountains and the rocks, 'Fall on us and hide us from the face of the One seated on the throne and from the wrath of the Lamb,'
verses.comment: This echoes Old Testament prophetic cries (Hos. 10:8). The image of the Lamb’s wrath is striking: Christ, usually associated with mercy, now enacts judgment, manifesting both His authority and divine justice. Christology is heightened here—His role in final judgment confirms His divinity and ultimate kingship.

verses.text: for the great day of their wrath has come, and who is able to stand?
verses.comment: The 'great day' points to the Day of the Lord, a phrase linking Scripture from Joel to Revelation. Only those found justified can endure God’s final judgment. This anticipates the sealing of the faithful in the next chapter—God’s Church, as the true and unified body, sheltered by His grace and preserved for glory.
